channel.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
channel.description:
So, what do you think it is?
If eBooks, then could some gracious soul link me to some? Thank you! :D

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“Sean, post:18, topic:40390”]Saevions contact details? Heh, you havent heard. He vanished off the face of the earth. The last time I talked to him on irc went along the lines of.

sean?
yeah?
nm

  • Quits seavion(irssi blah blah)

The mobile number I had was disconnected shortly after, later taken by some random guy who had to deal with me drunkenly calling one night His ip (static) responded to pings but his services (ssh and such) were gone. For all I know hes dead, went to japan, australia or somewhere (he was discussing going away for a year or two with me, possibly visiting me and such). Was a bit of a shock. Oh well.[/quote]

Damn…that’s pretty impressive.
edit: Was he from Florida?

[quote=“Sean, post:18, topic:40390”]And as for his work on converting it to asm im not sure if I have any of it lying around, I can have a dig around thou.

As for the group of developers, I have no idea - im not particurally interested in it tbh =[/quote]

I was talking about the fixed BCEL, but that’d be great too - I’d like to see how he set ASM to manipulation instead of generation.

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

Saevions contact details? Heh, you havent heard. He vanished off the face of the earth. The last time I talked to him on irc went along the lines of.

sean?
yeah?
nm

  • Quits seavion(irssi blah blah)

The mobile number I had was disconnected shortly after, later taken by some random guy who had to deal with me drunkenly calling one night His ip (static) responded to pings but his services (ssh and such) were gone. For all I know hes dead, went to japan, australia or somewhere (he was discussing going away for a year or two with me, possibly visiting me and such). Was a bit of a shock. Oh well.

And as for his work on converting it to asm im not sure if I have any of it lying around, I can have a dig around thou.

As for the group of developers, I have no idea - im not particurally interested in it tbh =\

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“Sean, post:16, topic:40390”]I wasnt actually aware of sun using bcel tbh with you, id have to look into that.

And as for the bugs, well, I dont know them off by heart, I could look them up for you. Once again I have to go back and say it was saevion that alerted me to them, I only used bcel for light things (not even made my own deober in my life time, im such a bytecode noob) but he was doing numerous bug fixes and submitting patches, getting involved in the developer polotics to try and sort the library out (this was before it died, some new developer took it over). But he was constantly sending me updated bcel jar files with bug fixes he had done himself, it got to the point he started writing his own. [/quote]

I’d be interested to see some of those, if you still have them (or even saevion’s contact info, if he wouldn’t mind?)

Sean:

I wouldnt go that far, aop obviously which javassist seams to be aimed at. Some other nieche frameworks (dynamic proxies and such do have their place here). But yeah it is indeed a niche, that isnt to say we shouldnt have one decent common framework for static manipluation of classfiles.

Bytecode weaving is only one way AOP is implemented, but you’re right - just because it’s a niche doesn’t mean it has to be devoid of good tools.

Sean:

ive done very very little work with the sound apis revolved around java, it really isnt a good area to be actively in development in atm due to the limited apis and tech going around for it, but there is some stuff… dunno how good it is… I remember never being able to find any decent mp3 stuff =p

Yeah, I wanted to do it in Java just because I’m most familiar with it, turns out that was a bad decision.

[quote=“Sean, post:16, topic:40390”][quote author=Krichevskoy link=topic=56614.msg717047#msg717047 date=1167631278]
Anyway, a project like that would require a team of dedicated and skilled coders, or we’d end up with something very much not worth the effort. What were some of the more glaring BCEL bugs, and do you know if Sun has done anything about them (doesn’t Sun use bits of BCEL in some of the more obscure API?)
[/quote]

And yes, it really would. It would be a longterm project requiring alot of effort and developers, but wouldnt it be fun? :)[/quote]

Yes, it would be
I’ve wanted to finish my own bytecode library for a while now, but lack time to do it all myself.
Do we have a suitable group of potential developers who might be interested?

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

I wasnt actually aware of sun using bcel tbh with you, id have to look into that.

And as for the bugs, well, I dont know them off by heart, I could look them up for you. Once again I have to go back and say it was saevion that alerted me to them, I only used bcel for light things (not even made my own deober in my life time, im such a bytecode noob) but he was doing numerous bug fixes and submitting patches, getting involved in the developer polotics to try and sort the library out (this was before it died, some new developer took it over). But he was constantly sending me updated bcel jar files with bug fixes he had done himself, it got to the point he started writing his own.

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:15, topic:40390”][quote author=Sean link=topic=56614.msg716069#msg716069 date=1167614163]
Sorry I didnt mean to sound like a dick there, but I did. I am not sure what I would suggest, I havent touched java bytecode stuff since I was in the rs “scene”, which I am certainly no longer a part of and have not been for a long time. And yes asm really dosent do what would be wanted in a good manner, saevion actually ported some of the deober to asm only to his own frustration.
[/quote]

Yeah, thing about bytecode manipulation is, it’s got almost ZERO application outside of reverse engineering/software protection, since the point of Java is to not think about how your code is actually being run on a given platform.[/quote]

I wouldnt go that far, aop obviously which javassist seams to be aimed at. Some other nieche frameworks (dynamic proxies and such do have their place here). But yeah it is indeed a niche, that isnt to say we shouldnt have one decent common framework for static manipluation of classfiles.

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:15, topic:40390”][quote author=Sean link=topic=56614.msg716069#msg716069 date=1167614163]
When I said look for alternatives I meant there MUST be a better api out there you guys could be using for this, which is in proper development. I mean, there MUST right? If not, hrm, why not pull together and make one? (Obviously this would be no trivial project, it would require alot of work and effort into it. But it could possibly fill a gap in the free software market and give some of the other developers here experiance in another area?)
[/quote]

That’s what I thought, too, but apparently we’re wrong.
In a similar vein, just try finding a decent (or even COMPLETE) free Java audio editing/DSP library…[/quote]

ive done very very little work with the sound apis revolved around java, it really isnt a good area to be actively in development in atm due to the limited apis and tech going around for it, but there is some stuff… dunno how good it is… I remember never being able to find any decent mp3 stuff =p

Krichevskoy:

Anyway, a project like that would require a team of dedicated and skilled coders, or we’d end up with something very much not worth the effort. What were some of the more glaring BCEL bugs, and do you know if Sun has done anything about them (doesn’t Sun use bits of BCEL in some of the more obscure API?)

And yes, it really would. It would be a longterm project requiring alot of effort and developers, but wouldnt it be fun?

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

Sean:

Sorry I didnt mean to sound like a dick there, but I did. I am not sure what I would suggest, I havent touched java bytecode stuff since I was in the rs “scene”, which I am certainly no longer a part of and have not been for a long time. And yes asm really dosent do what would be wanted in a good manner, saevion actually ported some of the deober to asm only to his own frustration.

Yeah, thing about bytecode manipulation is, it’s got almost ZERO application outside of reverse engineering/software protection, since the point of Java is to not think about how your code is actually being run on a given platform.

Sean:

When I said look for alternatives I meant there MUST be a better api out there you guys could be using for this, which is in proper development. I mean, there MUST right? If not, hrm, why not pull together and make one? (Obviously this would be no trivial project, it would require alot of work and effort into it. But it could possibly fill a gap in the free software market and give some of the other developers here experiance in another area?)

That’s what I thought, too, but apparently we’re wrong.
In a similar vein, just try finding a decent (or even COMPLETE) free Java audio editing/DSP library…

Anyway, a project like that would require a team of dedicated and skilled coders, or we’d end up with something very much not worth the effort. What were some of the more glaring BCEL bugs, and do you know if Sun has done anything about them (doesn’t Sun use bits of BCEL in some of the more obscure API?)

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

Sorry I didnt mean to sound like a dick there, but I did. I am not sure what I would suggest, I havent touched java bytecode stuff since I was in the rs “scene”, which I am certainly no longer a part of and have not been for a long time. And yes asm really dosent do what would be wanted in a good manner, saevion actually ported some of the deober to asm only to his own frustration.

I was never a big fan of javassist either tbh.

Never looked @ serp.

Never looked @ jclasslib.

When I said look for alternatives I meant there MUST be a better api out there you guys could be using for this, which is in proper development. I mean, there MUST right? If not, hrm, why not pull together and make one? (Obviously this would be no trivial project, it would require alot of work and effort into it. But it could possibly fill a gap in the free software market and give some of the other developers here experiance in another area?)

I will have a look and see if I can find anything thou.

edit1: I just had a quick look at jclasslib, and might I add a very quick look. It isnt going to do your bcel magics for pattern recognition, and it handles the opcodes as direct bytes so dont expect any magic here either. Its seems to me its a straight ol java class referance => pojos deal.

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

Sean:

Why are we still using bcel? The project was discontinued a long time ago and it had alot of glaring bugs which hadnt been fixed. Look into alternatives?

We’re still using BCEL because no one wants to write his own search methods. What alternatives would you suggest?

[ul][li]ASM is good, but it’s not really meant for editing existing classes like we do with BCEL.[/li]
[li]Javassist lacks search and power (though it does tie into an AOP framework).[/li]
[li]SERP, if I remember correctly, only supports the visitor model (not fatal, I just don’t like it).[/li]
[li]jclasslib has been suggested to me, but I haven’t looked into it.[/li][/ul]

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Leik pplsuqbawls’s library, written in 30 million lines of code and works faster than anything ever written, human or alien.

Why are we still using bcel? The project was discontinued a long time ago and it had alot of glaring bugs which hadnt been fixed. Look into alternatives?

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

You could give the BCELifier a shot. But it tends to produce ugly code.
org.apache.bcel.util.BCELifier

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:5, topic:40390”][quote author=RLN link=topic=56614.msg705352#msg705352 date=1167435741]
Theres no “best” way to learn an API, but instead of coming here and asking how to learn it, why don’t you just go learn it on your own? Just read the documentation, and if you know enough to actually use the API by yourself then you shouldn’t need someone to write you a tutorial.
[/quote]

There is nothing wrong with asking other people for suggestions, that is after all why we are here.

I find that learning by example is the best way to learn anything, at least with me.[/quote]
I find that the easiest way too

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote=“k00dr, post:7, topic:40390”][quote author=White Castle link=topic=56614.msg705815#msg705815 date=1167441517]
The way I did it was, just pick up the API and start fooling around with the RS client. Also, reading the VM Spec Chapter 4 helped alot since terminology used in there is used within BCEL. But I warn you, it’s a pretty heavy read.
[/quote]

I’m surprised how no one mentioned it before. :)[/quote]

Yeah, writing a class file reader from that was the most helpful thing I did to understand bytecode.

RLN has a point about asking how to learn an API, but would you say the same thing about another API? Say, OpenGL? No, you wouldn’t, tutorials are extremely helpful there if you don’t understand graphics theory - just as BCEL tutorials would be helpful to someone who is trying to understand bytecode theory.

Presenting existing information in a more understandable or concrete way does not equate to “spoon-feeding”

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

White Castle:

The way I did it was, just pick up the API and start fooling around with the RS client. Also, reading the VM Spec Chapter 4 helped alot since terminology used in there is used within BCEL. But I warn you, it’s a pretty heavy read.

I’m surprised how no one mentioned it before.

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

The way I did it was, just pick up the API and start fooling around with the RS client. Also, reading the VM Spec Chapter 4 helped alot since terminology used in there is used within BCEL. But I warn you, it’s a pretty heavy read.

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

On another topic

Theres no “best” way to learn an API, but instead of coming here and asking how to learn it, why don’t you just go learn it on your own? Just read the documentation, and if you know enough to actually use the API by yourself then you shouldn’t need someone to write you a tutorial.

There is nothing wrong with asking other people for suggestions, that is after all why we are here.

I find that learning by example is the best way to learn anything, at least with me.

Read full topic

item.title: Best way to learn BCEL?
item.dc:creator: @Kryptizzler Kryptizzler
item.description:

Looks over examples posted by other people - that might help.

I’m trying to do it by reading the manual over and over and using BCEL’s javadocs yet… I’m sure there’s a better way to do it.

I think this matter needs some tutorials…
